awd_titl_txt: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Improving Patient Flow in Hospitals
awd_abstract_narration:
This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) Program award will advance the national health by reducing congestion and improving patient flow within hospital units and between hospitals.  By developing models that predict flow dynamics and address sources of congestion, this project will improve patient safety and satisfaction, and at the same time reduce staffing and equipment costs to the hospital.  Reduced congestion will also improve occupancy prediction, thus reducing ambulance diversions within the hospital network.  This research employs novel modeling techniques that are informed by a close collaboration between the PIs and the GOALI partner, Northwestern Memorial Hospital (NMH).  Models will be developed that are easy to calibrate and sufficiently general, so that their analyses and insights are applicable in  a broad range of clinical settings within the hospital.  The award provides support for graduate students to engage in research that will be of direct benefit to healthcare operations.  The PIs will incorporate the results of their research in courses on queueing and service engineering.  The outcomes of the research will be disseminated to both the operations research and the healthcare practitioner communities.

This award supports research on multi-server queueing models, tailored specifically to hospital operations, that address key features of patient-flow dynamics.  These features include bursty departures due to periodic discharge windows and non-stationary arrival processes.  Because of the complexity of the dynamics, the research develops appropriate approximations for queueing phenomena based on fluid approximations during peak loads and infinite server approximations during lightly loaded periods.  These methods, in conjunction with high-fidelity simulations, will be used to characterize long-run behavior of the patient-flow process, such as the maximum throughput of hospital units, and their (periodic) time-dependent equilibria behavior under different operational policies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Due to the fundamental differences between hospital operations and most other service systems, existing queueing models lack pivotal features of hospital-related queueing dynamics, and are therefore not adequate for this setting. Hence, entirely different models must be developed. In this research project, we designed and analyzed new models for patient-flow dynamics in hospitals, which greatly facilitate our understanding of how different hospital units function. Further, our models also enable the optimization of hospitals’ patient-flow related operations.
In particular, we developed new paradigms for queueing models, based on a close collaboration with hospitals in the Chicago metropolitan area, and in particular with Northwestern Memorial Hospital (NMH), as well as data from hospitals in other countries. Those models include, for example, time-varying arrival patterns of patients, blocking of servers (beds) and ``bursty'' departure processes—phenomena that are ubiquitous in hospital units, but were not considered jointly in the literature. Due to the complexity of the queueing dynamics, exact analysis is futile, and so we developed different types of approximations, which were shown to be effective and accurate via comparison to the hospitals’ data and simulation experiments. Thus, in addition to our contribution to practice, our research also contributed to queueing theory, by providing novel models and analytical tools for the analysis of time-varying queues with jumps, as well as queues with different time scales, in the limiting approximations.

An important aspect of the models we developed is that they are easy to calibrate and are sufficiently general, so that the analyses and the insights obtained are applicable in broad settings, which are not specific to any one particular hospital. To facilitate the implementation of our solutions in practice, an easy-to-use toolbox was developed in Excel and was made available online with detailed instructions, so that other hospitals could employ our models in order to understand and optimize their operations.
Finally, the research work is part of the theses of two PhD students who have graduated from Northwestern University and Columbia University, and are currently assistant professors in leading universities.
